rawResponse:
no

The additional $900,000 (10% of $9 million) would complete a product that is already obsolete compared to the competitor's superior offering. The $8.1 million already spent is a sunk cost and shouldn't influence future decisions. Investing the remaining funds would likely result in a finished product with no market value, making it economically irrational to proceed.

no

The sunk cost fallacy applies here - the $9 million already invested should not factor into the decision. Since a competitor has already brought a superior product to market (faster and more economical), completing our inferior plane would likely result in minimal returns that wouldn't justify even the final 10% investment.

no

The sunk cost fallacy should not influence this decision. The $9 million already spent is irrelevant to the choice ahead. What matters is whether investing the remaining 10% ($900,000) will generate positive returns.

Since a competitor has already brought a superior product to market (faster, more economical, and also radar-blank), completing our inferior plane would likely result in minimal or negative returns on that final investment. The rational choice is to cut losses and redirect resources to more promising opportunities.

no

The sunk cost fallacy applies here - the $8.1 million already spent is irrelevant to the decision. What matters is whether investing the remaining $900,000 will generate positive returns. Since a competitor has already launched a superior product (faster and more economical), completing an inferior radar-blank plane would likely result in minimal market value, making the additional investment unprofitable.

no

The additional $900,000 (10% of $9 million) would complete a product that is already inferior to a competitor's offering in speed and economy. The $8.1 million already spent is a sunk cost and should not influence the decision. Investing more money into an inferior product that will likely fail in the market is not economically rational.

no

The additional $900,000 (10% of $9 million) would complete a product that is already obsolete - slower and less economical than a competitor's existing offering. The $8.1 million already spent is a sunk cost and shouldn't influence the decision. Investing the final 10% would only add to losses without creating a viable competitive product.
